messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> Gerry Fisher wrote:
> >
> > IDE: NetBeans 3.6
> > JUnit: junit3.8.1
> >
> > Here's my test case (minus individual tests):
> >
> > package test;
> >
> > import junit.framework.*;
> > import junit.swingui.TestRunner;
> > import scwcd.display.InfoRequestStore;
> >
> > public class InfoRequestStoreTest extends TestCase {
> >
> > private InfoRequestStore store;
> >
> > public InfoRequestStoreTest(String testName) {
> > super(testName);
> > }
> >
> > public static Test suite() {
> > return new TestSuite(InfoRequestStoreTest.class);
> > }
> >
> > public static void main(String[] args) {
> > //junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> > //junit.awtui.TestRunner.run(suite());
> > junit.swingui.TestRunner
> > .run(InfoRequestStoreTest.class);
> >
> > }
> > }
> >
> > The two commented-out lines in main() do not work. The
> > uncommented line is ok. When I try to compile I get
> > the
> > error message:
> >
> > "run(java.lang.Class) in junit.swingui.TestRunner
> > cannot be applied to (junit.framework.Test)"
>
> This looks like a compiler error, so I'm confused.
>
> BTW: both your suite() method and the constructor are superfluous. I
> recommend you remove them.
>
> Finally, I recommend running your tests this way:
>
> junit.swingui.TestRunner.main(new String[]
> {InfoRequestStoreTest.class.getName()});
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing

Joe,

Thanks for your reply. You are right that some of my code is redundant
as presently shown. I was just trying to illustrate a point. I've got
quite a few other test cases and I would like to run all of them
together as a single test suite rather than as a series of standalone
test cases. Thus,

1. junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(InfoRequestStoreTest.class) is fine.

2. junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(suite()) is not fine.

In the first example I'm passing a TestCase to TestRunner.run(). In
the second example I'm passing a TestSuite. Both TestCase and
TestSuite implement the Test interface. However, TestSuite cannot be
cast to Test. What puzzles me is that this failure to cast occurs in
junit.swingui.TestRunner.run() and junit.awtui.TestRunner.run() but
not in junit.textui.TestRunner.run().

I've read older messages at this site and it seems this is not an
unusual problem. The only difference that I can see is that they got
their code to compile but then encountered ClassCastException at
runtime. Whereas in my case I don't get as far as running the code
because this potential runtime exception is being picked up earlier
during compilation.

The recommended solution is to edit the excluded.properties file. In
my case I've added a new entry - excluded.9=test.* where 'test' is my
package name. This has had no effect and I wonder if I'm doing the
right thing.

Cheers
